p:
Physicians need to be aware that immunoglobulins are not specifically effective against SARS-CoV-2 because of a lack of specific antibodies within the product, but can help in preventing additional infections. Bacterial secondary infection can complicate viral infections, a situation well known in influenza, and emerging in COVID-19.
120, 121 Immunoglobulin replacement therapy reduces the risk of major infection in patients with CLL and low serum IgG.
122 Subcutaneous formulations are non-inferior to intravenous formulations with the advantage of being self-administered by patients at home after a short training.
123 Given the higher risk of thromboembolic events with COVID-19, we recommend assessment of risks vs. benefits in each patient and close monitoring for thromboembolic symptoms.
